**Tbilisi** ( English: [/təbɪˈliːsi, təˈbɪlɪsi/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/51/En-gb-Tbilisi.ogg/En-gb-Tbilisi.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:En-gb-Tbilisi.ogg "File:En-gb-Tbilisi.ogg")^ [*tə-bil-EE-see, tə-BIL-iss-ee*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key");^[\[7\]](#cite_note-epd-7)^ [Georgian](/wiki/Georgian_language "Georgian language"): თბილისი,
pronounced [\[ˈtʰbilisi\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Georgian "Help:IPA/Georgian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/64/Tbilisi.ogg/Tbilisi.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Tbilisi.ogg "File:Tbilisi.ogg")^), in some languages still known by its pre-1936 name **Tiflis^[\[a\]](#cite_note-8)^** ([/ˈtɪflɪs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/0/09/En-gb-Tiflis.ogg/En-gb-Tiflis.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:En-gb-Tiflis.ogg "File:En-gb-Tiflis.ogg")^ [*TIF-liss*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")),^[\[7\]](#cite_note-epd-7)^ ([Georgian](/wiki/Georgian_language "Georgian language"): ტფილისი, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Georgian "Romanization of Georgian"): t'pilisi [\[tʼpʰilisi\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Georgian "Help:IPA/Georgian")) is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Georgia_(country) "List of cities and towns in Georgia (country)") of [Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_(country) "Georgia (country)"), lying on the banks of the [Kura River](/wiki/Kura_(Caspian_Sea) "Kura (Caspian Sea)"). With around 1.2 million inhabitants, it contains almost one third of the country's population. Tbilisi was founded in the fifth century [AD](/wiki/Anno_Domini "Anno Domini") by [Vakhtang I of Iberia](/wiki/Vakhtang_I_of_Iberia "Vakhtang I of Iberia") and has since served as the capital of various Georgian kingdoms and republics. Between 1801 and 1917, then part of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), it was the seat of the [Caucasus Viceroyalty](/wiki/Caucasus_Viceroyalty_(1801%E2%80%931917) "Caucasus Viceroyalty (1801–1917)"), governing both the [northern](/wiki/North_Caucasus "North Caucasus") and the [southern](/wiki/South_Caucasus "South Caucasus") sides of the [Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus").^[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)^^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^{#cite_ref-10}

Because of its location at the crossroads between Europe and Asia, and its proximity to the lucrative [Silk Road](/wiki/Silk_Road "Silk Road"), throughout history, Tbilisi has been a point of contention among various global powers. To this day, the city's location ensures its position as an important transit route for energy and trade projects. Tbilisi's history is reflected in its unique architecture, which is a mix of [medieval](/wiki/Medieval_architecture "Medieval architecture"), [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture"), [Beaux Arts](/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture "Beaux-Arts architecture"), [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau"), [Stalinist](/wiki/Stalinist_architecture "Stalinist architecture"), and [Modern](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture") structures.

Historically, Tbilisi has been home to various people of diverse cultural, ethnic, and religious backgrounds, though its population is overwhelmingly [Eastern Orthodox Christian](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"). Notable tourist destinations include cathedrals [Sameba](/wiki/Holy_Trinity_Cathedral_of_Tbilisi "Holy Trinity Cathedral of Tbilisi") and [Sioni](/wiki/Tbilisi_Sioni_Cathedral "Tbilisi Sioni Cathedral"), [Freedom Square](/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Tbilisi "Freedom Square, Tbilisi"), [Rustaveli Avenue](/wiki/Rustaveli_Avenue "Rustaveli Avenue") and [Agmashenebeli Avenue](/wiki/David_Agmashenebeli_Avenue "David Agmashenebeli Avenue"), medieval [Narikala Fortress](/wiki/Narikala "Narikala"), the [pseudo-Moorish](/wiki/Moorish_Revival_architecture#Moorish_Revival_in_Europe "Moorish Revival architecture") [Opera Theater](/wiki/Georgian_National_Opera_Theater "Georgian National Opera Theater"), and the [Georgian National Museum](/wiki/Georgian_National_Museum "Georgian National Museum"). The climate in Tbilisi mostly ranges from 20 to 32 °C (68 to 90 °F) in summer and −1 to 7 °C (30 to 45 °F) in winter.  

Names and etymology {#Names_and_etymology}
------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Names and etymology")\]  
See also: [Names of Tbilisi in different languages](/wiki/Names_of_Tbilisi_in_different_languages "Names of Tbilisi in different languages")

The name "Tbilisi" derives from [Old Georgian](/wiki/Old_Georgian "Old Georgian") *Tbilisi* ([Asomtavruli](/wiki/Asomtavruli "Asomtavruli"): [ႧႡႨႪႨႱႨ](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%83%97%E1%83%91%E1%83%98%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98%E1%83%A1%E1%83%98#Old_Georgian "wikt:თბილისი"), [Mkhedruli](/wiki/Mkhedruli "Mkhedruli"): [თბილისი](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%83%97%E1%83%91%E1%83%98%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98%E1%83%A1%E1%83%98#Georgian "wikt:თბილისი")), and further from *tpili* ([Modern Georgian](/wiki/Georgian_language "Georgian language"): [თბილი](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%83%97%E1%83%91%E1%83%98%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98#Georgian "wikt:თბილი"), warm, itself from Old Georgian: [ႲႴႨႪႨ](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%83%A2%E1%83%A4%E1%83%98%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98#Old_Georgian "wikt:ტფილი") *ṭpili*). The name *Tbilisi* (the place of warmth) was therefore given to the city because of the area's numerous [sulfuric](/wiki/Sulfur "Sulfur") [hot springs](/wiki/Hot_spring "Hot spring").

Until 1936, the name of the city in English and most other languages followed the [Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language") pronunciation^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^ **Tiflis** , while the [Georgian](/wiki/Georgian_language "Georgian language") name was ტფილისი (*Ṭpilisi*).^[\[11\]](#cite_note-Tiflis-12)^{#cite_ref-Tiflis_12-0}

On 17 August 1936, by order of the [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") leadership, the official Russian names of various cities were changed to more closely match the local language.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-Tiflis-12)^ In addition, the Georgian-language form *Ṭpilisi* was modernized on the basis of a proposal by Georgian linguists; the ancient Georgian component ტფილი (*ṭpili*, 'warm') was replaced by the newer თბილი (*tbili*).^[\[11\]](#cite_note-Tiflis-12)^ That form was the basis for the new official Russian name (Тбилиси *Tbilisi*). Most other languages have subsequently adopted the new name form, but some languages, such as Turkish, Persian, [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"), [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"), and [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"), have retained a variation of *Tiflis*.{#cite_ref-Tiflis_12-2}

On 20 September 2006, the Georgian parliament held a ceremony celebrating the 70th anniversary of the renaming.

Some of the traditional names of Tbilisi in other languages of the region have different roots. The [Ossetian](/wiki/Ossetian_language "Ossetian language") name Калак (*Kalak*) derives from the Georgian word ქალაქი (*kalaki*) meaning simply city. [Chechen](/wiki/Chechen_language "Chechen language") and [Ingush](/wiki/Ingush_language "Ingush language") names for the city use a form similar to or the same as their names for the country of Georgia (Гуьржех *Gürƶex*) as does the historical [Kabardian](/wiki/Kabardian_language "Kabardian language") name (Курджы *Kwrdžə*), while [Abkhaz](/wiki/Abkhaz_language "Abkhaz language") Қарҭ (*Ķarţ*) is from the [Mingrelian](/wiki/Mingrelian_language "Mingrelian language") ქართი (*Karti*).

### Early history {#Early_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Early history")\]

Archaeologists discovered evidence of continuous habitation of the Tbilisi suburb of Dighomi since the early Bronze Age, and stone artifacts dating to the Paleolithic age.^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^{#cite_ref-13}

During the late Bronze Age to early Iron Age, it was the largest settlement in the Caucasus.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^ According to legend, the present-day territory of Tbilisi was covered by forests as late as 458. One widely accepted variant of the Tbilisi foundation myth states that King [Vakhtang I of Iberia](/wiki/Vakhtang_I_of_Iberia "Vakhtang I of Iberia") ( c. 447/49 -- 502/22) went hunting in the heavily wooded region with a [falcon](/wiki/Falcon "Falcon") (sometimes the falcon is replaced with either a [hawk](/wiki/Hawk "Hawk") or other small [birds of prey](/wiki/Birds_of_prey "Birds of prey") in the legend). The king's falcon allegedly caught or injured a [pheasant](/wiki/Pheasant "Pheasant") during the hunt, after which both birds fell into a nearby [hot spring](/wiki/Hot_spring "Hot spring") and died from burns. King Vakhtang became so impressed with the hot springs that he decided to clear the forest and build a city on the location.{#cite_ref-14}

King [Dachi of Iberia](/wiki/Dachi_of_Iberia "Dachi of Iberia") ( 522--534), the successor of Vakhtang I, moved the capital of Iberia from [Mtskheta](/wiki/Mtskheta "Mtskheta") to Tbilisi and began construction of the fortress wall that lined the city's new boundaries.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)^ From the sixth century, Tbilisi grew at a steady pace due to the region's strategic location along with important trade and travel routes between Europe and Asia.{#cite_ref-15}  

### Foreign domination {#Foreign_domination}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Foreign domination")\]

Tbilisi's favorable trade location, however, did not necessarily bode well for its survival. Located strategically in the heart of the [Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus") between Europe and Asia, Tbilisi became an object of rivalry among the region's various powers such as the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), [Parthia](/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire"), [Sassanid Persia](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire"), [Muslim Arabs](/wiki/Caliphate "Caliphate"), the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire"), and the [Seljuk Turks](/wiki/Seljuk_Empire "Seljuk Empire"). The cultural development of the city was somewhat dependent on who ruled the city at various times, although Tbilisi was fairly cosmopolitan.

From 570 to 580, the Persians ruled the city until 627, when [Tbilisi was sacked](/wiki/Third_Perso-Turkic_War "Third Perso-Turkic War") by the [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire")/[Khazar](/wiki/Khazars "Khazars") armies and later, in 736--738, Arab armies [entered](/wiki/Marwan_ibn_Muhammad%27s_invasion_of_Georgia "Marwan ibn Muhammad's invasion of Georgia") the town under [Marwan II](/wiki/Marwan_II "Marwan II"). After this point, the [Arabs](/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate "Rashidun Caliphate") established an [emirate](/wiki/Emirate_of_Tbilisi "Emirate of Tbilisi") centered in Tbilisi. [Arabic dirhams](/wiki/Dirham "Dirham") were brought to Georgia following the Arab conquest in the seventh century, and a mint was founded in Tbilisi that produced coins with inscriptions in both [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic") and Georgian.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMikaberidze2015242-16)^ In 764, Tbilisi -- still under Arab control -- was once again sacked by the Khazars. In 853, the armies of Arab leader [Bugha Al-Turki](/wiki/Bugha_al-Kabir "Bugha al-Kabir") invaded Tbilisi in order to enforce its return to [Abbasid](/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate "Abbasid Caliphate") allegiance. The Arab domination of Tbilisi continued until about 1050. In 1065, the [Seljuk](/wiki/Seljuk_dynasty "Seljuk dynasty") Sultan [Alp Arslan](/wiki/Alp_Arslan "Alp Arslan") campaigned against the [Kingdom of Georgia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Georgia "Kingdom of Georgia"), subjugated Tbilisi, and built a mosque in the city.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinorsky195365-17)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinorsky195365_17-0}  

### Capital of Georgia {#Capital_of_Georgia}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Capital of Georgia")\]

In 1121, after the [Battle of Didgori](/wiki/Battle_of_Didgori "Battle of Didgori") against the [Seljuks](/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty "Seljuq dynasty"), the troops of King [David IV of Georgia](/wiki/David_IV_of_Georgia "David IV of Georgia") besieged Tbilisi, taking it in 1122. David moved his residence from [Kutaisi](/wiki/Kutaisi "Kutaisi") to Tbilisi, making it the capital of a unified [Georgian State](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Georgia "Kingdom of Georgia"), thus inaugurating the [Georgian Golden Age](/wiki/Georgian_Golden_Age "Georgian Golden Age"). From the 12--13th centuries, Tbilisi became a regional power with a thriving economy and astonishing cultural output. By the end of the 12th century, the population of Tbilisi had reached 100,000. The city also became an important literary and cultural center, not only for Georgia, but also for the [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox") world of the time. During [Queen Tamar](/wiki/Queen_Tamar "Queen Tamar")'s reign, [Shota Rustaveli](/wiki/Shota_Rustaveli "Shota Rustaveli") worked in Tbilisi while writing his legendary epic poem *[The Knight in the Panther's Skin](/wiki/The_Knight_in_the_Panther%27s_Skin "The Knight in the Panther's Skin")* . This period is often referred to as "Georgia's Golden Age"^[\[17\]](#cite_note-18)^ or the Georgian [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^{#cite_ref-19}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Tiflis_-_Angelino_Dulcert_-_1339.jpg/220px-Tiflis_-_Angelino_Dulcert_-_1339.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiflis_-_Angelino_Dulcert_-_1339.jpg) Detail from the Nautical chart by [Angelino Dulcert](/wiki/Angelino_Dulcert "Angelino Dulcert"), depicting Georgian Black Sea coast and Tiflis, 1339

Tbilisi's "Golden Age" did not last for more than a century. In 1226, Tbilisi was captured by the [Khwarezmian Empire](/wiki/Khwarazmian_dynasty "Khwarazmian dynasty") under Shah [Jalal al-Din](/wiki/Jalal_al-Din_Mangburni "Jalal al-Din Mangburni"), who massacred tens of thousands of Christians.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMikaberidze201519-20)^ The Khwarezmian occupation left Tbilisi's defenses severely devastated and prone to further attacks by Mongol armies.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^ In 1236, after suffering crushing [Mongol defeats](/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Georgia "Mongol invasions of Georgia"), Georgia submitted to [Mongol domination](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Georgia#Mongol_yoke "Kingdom of Georgia"). The nation itself maintained a form of "semi-independence" and did not lose its statehood, but Tbilisi would be strongly influenced by the Mongols for the next century, both politically and culturally. In the 1320s, the Mongols retreated from Georgia, and Tbilisi became the capital of an independent Georgian state, once again. However, an outbreak of the [Black Death](/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death") struck the city in 1366.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^{#cite_ref-22}

Between the late 14th century and the late 18th century, Tbilisi would again be under the rule of various foreign powers. On several occasions, the city would even be completely burned and razed to the ground. In 1386, Tbilisi was [invaded and sacked several times](/wiki/Timur%27s_invasions_of_Georgia "Timur's invasions of Georgia") by the armies of [Tamerlane](/wiki/Timur "Timur"). In 1440, the city was [invaded](/wiki/Turkmen_incursions_into_Georgia "Turkmen incursions into Georgia") and destroyed by [Jahan Shah](/wiki/Jahan_Shah "Jahan Shah") (the Shah of the town of [Tabriz](/wiki/Tabriz "Tabriz"), [Persia](/wiki/Iran "Iran")). From 1477 to 1478, the city was held by the [Ak Koyunlu](/wiki/Aq_Qoyunlu "Aq Qoyunlu") tribesmen of [Uzun Hassan](/wiki/Uzun_Hasan "Uzun Hasan").  

### Iranian control {#Iranian_control}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Iranian control")\]  
See also: [Safavid Georgia](/wiki/Safavid_Georgia "Safavid Georgia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/03_Chardin_Tblisi_1671.jpg/220px-03_Chardin_Tblisi_1671.jpg)](/wiki/File:03_Chardin_Tblisi_1671.jpg) Tbilisi according to French traveler [Jean Chardin](/wiki/Jean_Chardin "Jean Chardin"), 1671 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Teflis_Tournefort.png/220px-Teflis_Tournefort.png)](/wiki/File:Teflis_Tournefort.png) A 1717 illustration of Teflis by [Joseph Pitton de Tournefort](/wiki/Joseph_Pitton_de_Tournefort "Joseph Pitton de Tournefort")

As early as the 1510s, Tbilisi (and the kingdoms of [Kartli](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kartli "Kingdom of Kartli") and [Kakheti](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kakheti "Kingdom of Kakheti")) were made vassal territories of [Safavid Iran](/wiki/Safavid_Iran "Safavid Iran").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERayfield2013164,_166-23)^ In 1522, Tbilisi was garrisoned for the first time by a large Safavid force.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHitchins2001464–470-24)^^[\[24\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERayfield2013166-25)^ Following the death of king (*[shah](/wiki/Shah "Shah")* ) [Ismail I](/wiki/Ismail_I "Ismail I") (r. 1501--1524), king [David X of Kartli](/wiki/David_X_of_Kartli "David X of Kartli") expelled the Iranians. During this period, many parts of Tbilisi were reconstructed and rebuilt. The four campaigns of the king [Tahmasp I](/wiki/Tahmasp_I "Tahmasp I") (r. 1524--1576) resulted in the reoccupation of Kartli and Kakheti, and a Safavid force was permanently stationed in Tbilisi from 1551 onwards.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHitchins2001464–470-24)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFloor2008295–296-26)^ With the 1555 [Treaty of Amasya](/wiki/Treaty_of_Amasya "Treaty of Amasya"), and more firmly from 1614 to 1747, with brief intermissions, Tbilisi was an important city under Iranian rule, and it functioned as a seat of the Iranian vassal kings of Kartli whom the shah conferred with the title of [vali](/wiki/Vali_(governor) "Vali (governor)"). In 1718, the Venetian senate implored the [Safavid emperor](/wiki/Safavid_Iran "Safavid Iran") [Soltan Hoseyn](/wiki/Soltan_Hoseyn "Soltan Hoseyn") to protect the Catholic Armenians and Capuchin missionaries in Tbilisi from the Gregorian Armenians.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERota2012152-27)^ Under the later rules of [Teimuraz II](/wiki/Teimuraz_II_of_Kakheti "Teimuraz II of Kakheti") and [Heraclius II](/wiki/Heraclius_II_of_Georgia "Heraclius II of Georgia"), Tbilisi became a vibrant political and cultural center free of foreign rule---but, fearful of the constant threat of invasion, Georgia's rulers sought Russian protection in the 1783 [Treaty of Georgievsk](/wiki/Treaty_of_Georgievsk "Treaty of Georgievsk"). Despite this agreement, the city was [captured and devastated](/wiki/Battle_of_Krtsanisi "Battle of Krtsanisi") in 1795 by the Iranian [Qajar](/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty") ruler [Agha Mohammad Khan](/wiki/Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar "Agha Mohammad Khan Qajar"), who sought to re-establish Iran's traditional sovereignty over the region.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKazemzadeh1991328–330-28)^^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^{#cite_ref-30}  

### Russian control {#Russian_control}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Russian control")\]  
See also: [Georgia within the Russian Empire](/wiki/Georgia_within_the_Russian_Empire "Georgia within the Russian Empire")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Coat_of_arms_of_Tiflis_Governorate_1878.svg/170px-Coat_of_arms_of_Tiflis_Governorate_1878.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Tiflis_Governorate_1878.svg) The coat of arms of Tiflis under Russian rule

In 1801, the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") annexed the Georgian [Kingdom of Kartli-Kakheti](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kartli-Kakheti "Kingdom of Kartli-Kakheti") (of which Tbilisi was the capital), later cementing its rule with the [Treaty of Gulistan](/wiki/Treaty_of_Gulistan "Treaty of Gulistan") of 1813,^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^ which ended Iranian control of Georgia.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ Within Tsarist Russia, Tbilisi (known then as Tiflis) was included within the [Tiflis Uyezd](/wiki/Tiflis_Uyezd "Tiflis Uyezd") county in 1801, and became the administrative center of the [Tiflis Governorate](/wiki/Tiflis_Governorate "Tiflis Governorate") (*[Gubernia](/wiki/Governorate_(Russia) "Governorate (Russia)")* ) following the latter's establishment in 1846. Russian Imperial administrators implemented a new European-style city plan and commissioned new buildings in Western styles. Roads and railroads were built to connect Tbilisi to other important cities in the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), such as [Batumi](/wiki/Batumi "Batumi") and [Poti](/wiki/Poti "Poti"). By the 1850s, Tbilisi once again emerged as a major trade and cultural center. The likes of [Ilia Chavchavadze](/wiki/Ilia_Chavchavadze "Ilia Chavchavadze"), [Akaki Tsereteli](/wiki/Akaki_Tsereteli "Akaki Tsereteli"), [Mirza Fatali Akhundzade](/wiki/Mirza_Fatali_Akhundov "Mirza Fatali Akhundov"), [Iakob Gogebashvili](/wiki/Iakob_Gogebashvili "Iakob Gogebashvili"), [Alexander Griboyedov](/wiki/Alexander_Griboyedov "Alexander Griboyedov") and many other statesmen, poets and artists all found their home in Tbilisi. The city was visited on numerous occasions by and was the object of affection of [Alexander Pushkin](/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin "Alexander Pushkin"), [Leo Tolstoy](/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy "Leo Tolstoy"), [Mikhail Lermontov](/wiki/Mikhail_Lermontov "Mikhail Lermontov"), the [Romanov family](/wiki/House_of_Romanov "House of Romanov") and others. The main new artery built under Russian administration was Golovin Avenue (present-day [Rustaveli Avenue](/wiki/Rustaveli_Avenue "Rustaveli Avenue")), on which the [Viceroys of the Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus_Viceroyalty_(1801%E2%80%931917) "Caucasus Viceroyalty (1801–1917)") established their residence. For much of the early 19th century, Tbilisi's largest ethnic group was Armenian, at some point forming 74.3% of the population.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-Ronald_Grigor_Suny_1994_116-34)^{#cite_ref-Ronald_Grigor_Suny_1994_116_34-0}

### Brief independence {#Brief_independence}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Brief independence")\]

After the [Russian Revolution of 1917](/wiki/Russian_Revolution "Russian Revolution"), the city served as a location of the [Transcaucasus](/wiki/Transcaucasia "Transcaucasia") interim government which established, in the spring of 1918, the short-lived independent [Transcaucasian Federation](/wiki/Transcaucasian_Democratic_Federative_Republic "Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic") with the capital in Tbilisi. At this time, Tbilisi had roughly the same number of Armenians as Georgians, with Russians being the third largest ethnic group.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-35)^ It was in the former Viceroy of the Caucasus's palace where the independence of three Transcaucasus nations -- Georgia, [Armenia](/wiki/Armenia "Armenia") and [Azerbaijan](/wiki/Azerbaijan "Azerbaijan") -- was declared by their respective national councils on 26 to 28 May 1918. After this, Tbilisi functioned as the capital of the [Democratic Republic of Georgia](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Georgia "Democratic Republic of Georgia") until 25 February 1921. From 1918 to 1919, the city also consecutively served as the headquarters of the country's [German](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire") garrison^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ and later the [British](/wiki/British_Army "British Army") [27th Division](/wiki/27th_Division_(United_Kingdom) "27th Division (United Kingdom)");^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^ Tbilisi was also the main office of the British Chief Commissioner in Transcaucasia, [Oliver Wardrop](/wiki/Oliver_Wardrop "Oliver Wardrop")^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ and the High Commissioner to Armenia, Colonel [William N. Haskell](/wiki/William_N._Haskell "William N. Haskell").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}

Under the national government, Tbilisi turned into the first Caucasian University City after the [Tbilisi State University](/wiki/Tbilisi_State_University "Tbilisi State University") was founded in 1918.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^ On 25 February 1921, the [Bolshevist Russian](/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic "Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic") 11th [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") invaded^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ Tbilisi and after bitter fighting at the outskirts of the city, declared Soviet rule.{#cite_ref-41}  

### Soviet rule {#Soviet_rule}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Soviet rule")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Red_Army_in_Tbilisi_Feb_25_1921.jpg/220px-Red_Army_in_Tbilisi_Feb_25_1921.jpg)](/wiki/File:Red_Army_in_Tbilisi_Feb_25_1921.jpg) The Red Army [entered](/wiki/Red_Army_invasion_of_Georgia "Red Army invasion of Georgia") Tbilisi on 25 February 1921

In 1921, the [Democratic Republic of Georgia](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Georgia "Democratic Republic of Georgia") was [occupied](/wiki/Red_Army_invasion_of_Georgia "Red Army invasion of Georgia") by the Soviet [Bolshevik](/wiki/Bolsheviks "Bolsheviks") forces from Russia, and until 1936, Tbilisi functioned first as the capital city of the [Transcaucasian SFSR](/wiki/Transcaucasian_Socialist_Federative_Soviet_Republic "Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic") (which included Armenia, [Azerbaijan](/wiki/Azerbaijan "Azerbaijan"), and Georgia), and afterward until 1991 as the capital of the [Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Georgian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic"). During Soviet rule, Tbilisi's population grew significantly, the city became more industrialized, and it also came to be an important political, social, and cultural centre of the Soviet Union. In 1980, the city hosted the first state-sanctioned [rock festival](/wiki/Tbilisi_Rock_Festival_(1980) "Tbilisi Rock Festival (1980)") in the USSR. As a major tourist destination for both Soviet citizens and foreign visitors, Tbilisi's "Old Town" (the neighborhoods within the original city walls) was reconstructed in the 1970s and 1980s.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^{#cite_ref-42}

Tbilisi witnessed mass anti-Russian demonstrations during 1956 in the [9 March Massacre](/wiki/1956_Georgian_demonstrations "1956 Georgian demonstrations"), in protest against the anti-Stalin policies of [Nikita Khrushchev](/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev "Nikita Khrushchev"). [Peaceful protests](/wiki/1978_Georgian_demonstrations "1978 Georgian demonstrations") occurred in 1978, and in 1989 the [April 9 tragedy](/wiki/April_9_tragedy "April 9 tragedy") was a peaceful protest that turned violent.  

### Post-independence {#Post-independence}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Post-independence")\]

Since the [break-up of the Soviet Union](/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1982%E2%80%9391) "History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)"), Tbilisi has experienced periods of significant instability and turmoil. After a brief civil war, which the city endured for two weeks from December 1991 to January 1992 (when pro-[Gamsakhurdia](/wiki/Zviad_Gamsakhurdia "Zviad Gamsakhurdia") and Opposition forces clashed), Tbilisi became the scene of frequent armed confrontations among various [mafia](/wiki/Russian_mafia "Russian mafia") clans and illegal business operators. During the [Shevardnadze](/wiki/Eduard_Shevardnadze "Eduard Shevardnadze") Era (1992--2003), crime and corruption were rampant. Many segments of society became impoverished because of unemployment caused by the crumbling economy. Average citizens of Tbilisi started to become increasingly disillusioned with the existing quality of life in the city (and in the nation in general). Mass protests took place in November 2003 after falsified parliamentary elections forced more than 100,000 people into the streets and concluded with the [Rose Revolution](/wiki/Rose_Revolution "Rose Revolution"). Since 2003, Tbilisi has experienced considerably more stability with decreasing crime rates, an improved economy, and a real estate boom.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^ During the [2008 South Ossetia war](/wiki/Russo-Georgian_War "Russo-Georgian War"), the Tbilisi area was hit by multiple Russian air attacks.{#cite_ref-43}

After the war, several large-scale projects were started, including a streetcar system,^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^ a railway bypass and a relocation of the [central station](/wiki/Tbilisi_railway_station "Tbilisi railway station"),^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ and new urban highways.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ In June 2015, [a flood](/wiki/2015_Tbilisi_flood "2015 Tbilisi flood") killed at least twenty people and caused animals from the [city's zoo](/wiki/Tbilisi_Zoo "Tbilisi Zoo") to be released into the streets.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}  

Politics and administration {#Politics_and_administration}
----------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Politics and administration")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tbilisi_City_Council%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-Tbilisi_City_Council%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tbilisi_City_Council,_Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) City Council building overlooking [Freedom Square](/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Tbilisi "Freedom Square, Tbilisi")  
See also: [List of mayors of Tbilisi](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Tbilisi "List of mayors of Tbilisi") and [Tbilisi City Assembly](/wiki/Tbilisi_City_Assembly "Tbilisi City Assembly")

The status of Tbilisi, as the nation's capital, is defined by Article 10 of the [Constitution of Georgia](/wiki/Constitution_of_Georgia_(country) "Constitution of Georgia (country)") (1995) and the *Law on Georgia's Capital -- Tbilisi* (20 February 1998).^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^{#cite_ref-48}

Tbilisi is governed by the [Tbilisi City Assembly](/wiki/Tbilisi_City_Assembly "Tbilisi City Assembly") (Sakrebulo) and the [Tbilisi City Hall](/wiki/Tbilisi_City_Hall "Tbilisi City Hall") (Meria). The City Assembly and mayor are elected once every four years by direct elections. The [Mayor of Tbilisi](/wiki/Mayor_of_Tbilisi "Mayor of Tbilisi") is [Kakha Kaladze](/wiki/Kakha_Kaladze "Kakha Kaladze") and the Chairman of the Tbilisi city Assembly is Giorgi Alibegashvili.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Tbilisi-Aghmashenebeli-08-113-2019-gje.jpg/220px-Tbilisi-Aghmashenebeli-08-113-2019-gje.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tbilisi-Aghmashenebeli-08-113-2019-gje.jpg) A police station on [Agmashenebeli Avenue](/wiki/David_Agmashenebeli_Avenue "David Agmashenebeli Avenue")

Administratively, the city is divided into [raions](/wiki/Raion "Raion") (districts), which have their own units of central and local government with jurisdiction over a limited scope of affairs. This subdivision was established under Soviet rule in the 1930s, following the general [subdivision of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_the_Soviet_Union "Subdivisions of the Soviet Union"). After Georgia regained independence, the raion system was modified and reshuffled. According to the latest revision, Tbilisi raions include:

Most of the raions are named after historic quarters of the city. The citizens of Tbilisi widely recognize an informal system of smaller historic neighborhoods. Such neighborhoods are several, however, constituting a kind of hierarchy, because most of them have lost their distinctive topographic limits. The natural first level of subdivision of the city is into the right and left banks of the Mtkvari river.

The names of the oldest neighborhoods go back to the early Middle Ages and sometimes pose a great linguistic interest. The newest whole-built developments bear chiefly residential marketing names.

In 19th-century Tbilisi, the Georgian quarter was confined to the southeastern part of the city; Baedeker describes the layout succinctly:
> In the north part of the town, on the left bank of the Kurá and to the south of the railway station, stretches the clean German Quarter, formerly occupied by German immigrants from Württemberg (1818). To the south is the Gruzinian or Georgian Quarter (Avlabár). On the right bank of the Kurá is the Russian Quarter, the seat of the officials and of the larger business firms. This is adjoined on the south by the Armenian and Persian Bazaars.  
--- Karl Baedeker, *Russia: A Handbook for Travelers* ^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Fortress_and_Old_Town_of_Tbilisi_at_dusk%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-Fortress_and_Old_Town_of_Tbilisi_at_dusk%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fortress_and_Old_Town_of_Tbilisi_at_dusk,_Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) Tbilisi, especially Old Town, has a complex terrain, with hills and cliffs. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Botanic_Garden%2C_Tbilisi.jpg/220px-Botanic_Garden%2C_Tbilisi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Botanic_Garden,_Tbilisi.jpg) The [National Botanical Garden of Georgia](/wiki/National_Botanical_Garden_of_Georgia "National Botanical Garden of Georgia") in Tbilisi is concealed from view as it resides among the hills of the Sololaki Range.  

### Location {#Location}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Location")\]

Tbilisi is located in the [South Caucasus](/wiki/Transcaucasia "Transcaucasia") at 41° 43' North and 44° 47' East. The city lies in [Eastern Georgia](/wiki/Eastern_Georgia_(country) "Eastern Georgia (country)") on both banks of the [Kura River](/wiki/Kura_(Caspian_Sea) "Kura (Caspian Sea)") (locally known as Mtkvari). The elevation of the city ranges from 380--770 metres [above sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level") (1,250--2,530 ft) and has the shape of an amphitheatre surrounded by mountains on three sides. To the north, Tbilisi is bounded by the [Saguramo Range](/wiki/Saguramo_Range "Saguramo Range"), to the east and south-east by the [Iori Plain](/w/index.php?title=Iori_Plain&action=edit&redlink=1 "Iori Plain (page does not exist)"), to the south and west by various endings (subranges) of the [Trialeti Range](/wiki/Trialeti_Range "Trialeti Range").

The relief of Tbilisi is complex. The part of the city which lies on the left bank of the Kura River extends for more than 30 km (19 mi) from the [Avchala](/wiki/Avchala "Avchala") District to River Lochini. The part of the city which lies on the right side of the river, though, is built along the foothills of the [Trialeti Range](/wiki/Trialeti_Range "Trialeti Range"), the slopes of which in many cases descend all the way to the edges of the river. The mountains, therefore, are a significant barrier to urban development on its right bank. This type of a geographic environment creates pockets of very densely developed areas, while other parts of the city are left undeveloped due to the complex topographic relief.

To the north of the city, a large reservoir (commonly known as the Tbilisi Sea) is fed by irrigation canals.  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Tbilisi_sea_09.23.jpg/220px-Tbilisi_sea_09.23.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tbilisi_sea_09.23.jpg) [Tbilisi Sea](/wiki/Tbilisi_Sea "Tbilisi Sea"), the city's largest body of water located in the suburbs.

Tbilisi has a [humid temperate climate](/wiki/Humid_temperate_climate "Humid temperate climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *[Cfa](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate"),* [Trewartha](/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification "Trewartha climate classification"): *[Do](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate")* ) with considerable [continental](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") and [semi-arid](/wiki/Semi-arid_climate "Semi-arid climate") influences. The city experiences hot, humid summers and moderately cold dry winters. Like other regions of Georgia, Tbilisi receives significant rainfall throughout the year with no distinct dry period. The city's climate is influenced both by dry (Central Asian/Siberian) air masses from the east and [oceanic](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") (Atlantic/Black Sea) air masses from the west. Because the city is bounded on most sides by mountain ranges, the close proximity to large bodies of water (Black and [Caspian Seas](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea")) and the fact that the Greater [Caucasus Mountains](/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains "Caucasus Mountains") Range (further to the north) blocks the intrusion of cold air masses from Russia, Tbilisi has a relatively mild [microclimate](/wiki/Microclimate "Microclimate") compared to other cities that possess a similar climate along the same latitudes.

The average annual temperature in Tbilisi is 13.8 °C (56.8 °F). January is the coldest month with an average temperature of 2.7 °C (36.9 °F). July is the hottest month with an average temperature of 25.4 °C (77.7 °F). Daytime high temperatures reach or exceed 32 °C (90 °F) on an average of 22 days during a typical year. The absolute minimum recorded temperature is −24.4 °C (−11.9 °F) in January 1883 and the absolute maximum is 42.0 °C (107.6 °F) on 17 July 1882.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-pogoda-52)^ Average annual precipitation is 511.5 mm (20.1 in). May is the wettest month (averaging 84.0 mm (3.3 in) of precipitation) while January is the driest (averaging 16.4 mm (0.6 in) of precipitation). Snow falls on average 15--25 days per year. The surrounding mountains often trap the clouds within and around the city, mainly during the Spring and Autumn months, resulting in prolonged rainy and/or cloudy weather. Northwesterly winds dominate in most parts of Tbilisi throughout the year. Southeasterly winds are common as well.{#cite_ref-pogoda_52-0}

[Main ethnic groups of Tbilisi]

As a multiethnic city, Tbilisi is home to more than 100 [ethnic](/wiki/Ethnic "Ethnic") groups. Around 90% of the population consists of ethnic [Georgians](/wiki/Georgians "Georgians"), with significant populations of other ethnic groups such as [Armenians](/wiki/Armenians_in_Tbilisi "Armenians in Tbilisi"), [Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians"), and [Azerbaijanis](/wiki/Azerbaijanis "Azerbaijanis"). Along with the above-mentioned groups, Tbilisi is home to other ethnic groups including [Ossetians](/wiki/Ossetians "Ossetians"), [Abkhazians](/wiki/Abkhazians "Abkhazians"), [Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians"), [Greeks](/wiki/Greeks "Greeks"), [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews"), [Assyrians](/wiki/Assyrian_people "Assyrian people"), [Yazidis](/wiki/Yazidis "Yazidis"), and others.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-Ronald_Grigor_Suny_1994_116-34)^^[\[34\]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-35)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-tiflis-61)^^[\[61\]](#cite_note-Suny1994-62)^^[\[66\]](#cite_note-statistics2002-69)^{#cite_ref-statistics2002_69-1}  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Religion")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/72/Sameba_Cathedral%2C_Holy_Trinity_Cathedral%2C_Dusk%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-Sameba_Cathedral%2C_Holy_Trinity_Cathedral%2C_Dusk%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sameba_Cathedral,_Holy_Trinity_Cathedral,_Dusk,_Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) Sameba Cathedral

More than 95% of the residents of Tbilisi practise some form of Christianity (the most predominant of which is the [Georgian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Georgian_Orthodox_Church "Georgian Orthodox Church")). The [Russian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church "Russian Orthodox Church"), which is in [full communion](/wiki/Full_communion "Full communion") with the Georgian Orthodox Church, and the [Armenian Apostolic Church](/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic_Church "Armenian Apostolic Church") have significant followings as well. A minority of the population (around 1.5%) practises [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") (mainly [Shia Islam](/wiki/Shia_Islam "Shia Islam")), while about 0.1% of Tbilisi's population practises [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism").^[\[68\]](#cite_note-71)^ Also, a [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") church and the [Yazidi](/wiki/Yezidism "Yezidism") [Sultan Ezid Temple](/wiki/Sultan_Ezid_Temple "Sultan Ezid Temple") can be found in the city.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-72)^^[\[70\]](#cite_note-73)^{#cite_ref-73}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Sports")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/2015_UEFA_Super_Cup_11.jpg/220px-2015_UEFA_Super_Cup_11.jpg)](/wiki/File:2015_UEFA_Super_Cup_11.jpg) Preparations for the [2015 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2015_UEFA_Super_Cup "2015 UEFA Super Cup") at the [Dinamo Arena](/wiki/Boris_Paichadze_Stadium "Boris Paichadze Stadium") in Tbilisi

Until the beginning of the 19th century, sports such as horse-riding ([polo](/wiki/Polo "Polo") in particular), [wrestling](/wiki/Wrestling "Wrestling"), [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing"), and [marksmanship](/wiki/Marksmanship "Marksmanship") were the most popular city sports. Influence from the Russian Empire brought more Western sports and activities (billiards, fencing) to Tbilisi.

The Soviet period brought an increased popularization of sports that were common in Europe and, to a certain extent, the United States. At the same time, Tbilisi developed the necessary infrastructure for professional sports. By 1978, the city had around 250 large and small sports facilities, including, among others, four indoor and six outdoor Olympic-sized pools, 185 basketball courts and halls, 192 volleyball facilities, 82 [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball") arenas, 19 tennis courts, 31 football fields, and five stadiums. The largest stadium in Tbilisi is the [Dinamo Arena](/wiki/Dinamo_Arena "Dinamo Arena") (55,000 seats) and the second-largest is the [Mikheil Meskhi Stadium](/wiki/Mikheil_Meskhi_Stadium "Mikheil Meskhi Stadium") (24,680 seats). The [Sports Palace](/wiki/Sports_Palace_(Tbilisi) "Sports Palace (Tbilisi)"), which usually hosts basketball games with high attendance and tennis tournaments, can seat about 11,000 people. [Vere Basketball Hall](/w/index.php?title=Vere_Basketball_Hall&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vere Basketball Hall (page does not exist)") is a smaller [indoor sports arena](/wiki/Indoor_arena "Indoor arena") with a [seating capacity](/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") of 2,500.

[Football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is the most popular sport in Tbilisi, followed by [rugby](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") and [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball").^[\[71\]](#cite_note-74)^ Other popular sports include [wrestling](/wiki/Wrestling "Wrestling"), [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis"), [swimming](/wiki/Swimming_(sport) "Swimming (sport)"), and [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water polo"). It has several professional football and rugby teams, as well as wrestling clubs. U.S. [National Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association") players [Zaza Pachulia](/wiki/Zaza_Pachulia "Zaza Pachulia") and [Nikoloz Tskitishvili](/wiki/Nikoloz_Tskitishvili "Nikoloz Tskitishvili") are Tbilisi natives. Outside of professional sports, the city has a number of intercollegiate and amateur sports teams and clubs.{#cite_ref-74}

Tbilisi's signature football club, [Dinamo Tbilisi](/wiki/FC_Dinamo_Tbilisi "FC Dinamo Tbilisi"), has not won a major European championship since the [1980--1981](/wiki/1980%E2%80%9381_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "1980–81 European Cup Winners' Cup") season, when it won the European [UEFA Cup Winners' Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup") and became the easternmost team in Europe to achieve the feat. The basketball club Dinamo Tbilisi won the [Euroleague](/wiki/Euroleague "Euroleague") in [1962](/wiki/FIBA_European_Champions_Cup_1961-62 "FIBA European Champions Cup 1961-62"), but also never repeated any such feat.

Tbilisi hosted Group A matches for the [EuroBasket 2022](/wiki/EuroBasket_2022 "EuroBasket 2022") at the new 10,000-seat Tbilisi Arena (next to the [Olympic Palace](/wiki/Olympic_Palace "Olympic Palace")), as one of the tournament co-hosts alongside Czech Republic (Prague), Germany (Berlin, Cologne), and Italy (Milan).^[\[72\]](#cite_note-75)^^[\[73\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Media")\]

The large majority of Georgia's media companies (including television, newspaper, and radio) are headquartered in Tbilisi. The city is home to the popular television channels [Rustavi 2](/wiki/Rustavi_2 "Rustavi 2"), [Imedi](/wiki/Imedi_Media_Holding "Imedi Media Holding"), [TV Pirveli](https://ka.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_%E1%83%9E%E1%83%98%E1%83%A0%E1%83%95%E1%83%94%E1%83%9A%E1%83%98 "ka:TV პირველი"), [Mtavari Arkhi](/wiki/Mtavari_Arkhi "Mtavari Arkhi"), [Formula](https://ka.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E1%83%A4%E1%83%9D%E1%83%A0%E1%83%9B%E1%83%A3%E1%83%9A%E1%83%90_(%E1%83%A2%E1%83%94%E1%83%9A%E1%83%94%E1%83%99%E1%83%9D%E1%83%9B%E1%83%9E%E1%83%90%E1%83%9C%E1%83%98%E1%83%90) "ka:ფორმულა (ტელეკომპანია)"), [Maestro](/wiki/Maestro_(TV_channel) "Maestro (TV channel)"), and the Public Broadcasting Channel, among others. Tbilisi's television market has experienced notable changes since 2019, when changes in the ownership of Rustavi 2 prompted many of its employees to leave and partake in the creation of new television channels, namely Mtavari Arkhi and TV Formula.

Tbilisi has a number of newspaper publishing houses. Some of the most noteworthy newspapers include the daily *24 Saati* ("24 Hours"), *Rezonansi* ("Resonance"), *Alia* , the English-language daily *The Messenger* , weekly *FINANCIAL, Georgia Today* , and the English-language weekly *The Georgian Times* . Out of the city's radio stations Imedi Radio (105.9 [FM](/wiki/FM_broadcasting "FM broadcasting")), Fortuna, and Radio 105 are some of the most influential competitors with large national audiences.

Radio stations in Tbilisi include 5 Lines Radio (93.8 FM), Europe +Tbilisi (99.6 FM), and Georgian Patriarchy Radio (105.4 FM).^[\[74\]](#cite_note-77)^{#cite_ref-77}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Architecture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Rustaveli_National_Theater_in_Georgia_%28Europe%29%2C_built_19th_century_in_Rococo_style.jpg/220px-Rustaveli_National_Theater_in_Georgia_%28Europe%29%2C_built_19th_century_in_Rococo_style.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rustaveli_National_Theater_in_Georgia_(Europe),_built_19th_century_in_Rococo_style.jpg) [Rustaveli Theatre](/wiki/Rustaveli_Theatre "Rustaveli Theatre") seen on the [Rustaveli Avenue](/wiki/Rustaveli_Avenue "Rustaveli Avenue")

The architecture in the city is a mixture of local (Georgian) and [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire"), [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture"), [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau"), [Beaux-Arts](/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture "Beaux-Arts architecture"), Middle Eastern, and Soviet modern styles.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-78)^ Very few buildings survived the destruction of the city in 1795, so most historical buildings in Tbilisi date to the Russian Imperial period (1801--1917). The oldest parts of the city (Kala, Abanotubani, Avlabari) were largely rebuilt on their medieval street plans, and some old houses were even rebuilt on much older foundations. The areas of downtown Tbilisi which were developed according to a European-style plan by Russian authorities (Sololaki, Rustaveli Avenue, Vera, etc.) have a Western appearance, with a mix of styles popular in Europe at the time: Beaux Arts, Orientalist, and various period revival styles.{#cite_ref-78}

Tbilisi is most notable for its abundance of Art Nouveau buildings and details (common in Sololaki and Chughureti), which flourished from the mid-1890s to through the end of Russian rule. Art Nouveau was decreed as bourgeois by communist authorities, who introduced experimental modern architecture. The more conservative and historically inflected [Stalinist architecture](/wiki/Stalinist_architecture "Stalinist architecture") in Georgia is embodied by the 1938 Marx-Engels-Lenin Institute building ("Imeli"), now housing the [Biltmore Hotel Tbilisi](/wiki/Biltmore_Hotel_Tbilisi "Biltmore Hotel Tbilisi").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/2014_Tbilisi%2C_Ulica_Erekle_II_%2803%29.jpg/170px-2014_Tbilisi%2C_Ulica_Erekle_II_%2803%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2014_Tbilisi,_Ulica_Erekle_II_(03).jpg) Open-air cafés in [Old Tbilisi](/wiki/Old_Tbilisi "Old Tbilisi")

Tbilisi's postwar architecture is similar to the brand of midcentury modernism found across the Soviet Union. The city expanded dramatically in response to a housing crisis after World War II. Entire neighborhoods (Saburtalo, Dighomi) appeared on the outskirts of the city in a matter of decades, built with advances in mass-production technology. Georgian architects produced some of the Soviet Union's most interesting architectural achievements, including Tbilisi's 1975 [Ministry of Roads](/wiki/Bank_of_Georgia_headquarters "Bank of Georgia headquarters") and the 1984 [Wedding Palace](/wiki/Wedding_Palace_(Tbilisi) "Wedding Palace (Tbilisi)"). Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the urban landscape is largely characterized by unregulated construction. New towers occupy formerly public spaces and overcrowded apartment buildings sprout "kamikaze loggia" overnight. Since 2004, the city government has taken initiatives to curb uncontrolled construction projects with mixed success. Tbilisi now has several skyscraper complexes, such as the [Axis Towers](https://ka.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E1%83%90%E1%83%A5%E1%83%A1%E1%83%98%E1%83%A1_%E1%83%97%E1%83%90%E1%83%A3%E1%83%94%E1%83%A0%E1%83%A1%E1%83%98 "ka:აქსის თაუერსი"), [Hilton Garden Inn Tbilisi Chavchavadze](/w/index.php?title=Hilton_Garden_Inn_Tbilisi_Chavchavadze&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hilton Garden Inn Tbilisi Chavchavadze (page does not exist)"), [Holiday Inn Tbilisi](/w/index.php?title=Holiday_Inn_Tbilisi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Holiday Inn Tbilisi (page does not exist)"), and [King David Residences](/w/index.php?title=King_David_Residences&action=edit&redlink=1 "King David Residences (page does not exist)").  

### Art museums and galleries {#Art_museums_and_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Art museums and galleries")\]

The [Georgian National Museum](/wiki/Georgian_National_Museum "Georgian National Museum") gathers several important museums, including the [Art Museum of Georgia](/wiki/Shalva_Amiranashvili_Museum_of_Fine_Arts "Shalva Amiranashvili Museum of Fine Arts"). The Museum of Modern Art was founded in 2012.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-79)^^\[*[unreliable source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Reliable sources")*\]^ Two independent contemporary art organizations, [Kunsthalle Tbilisi](/w/index.php?title=Kunsthalle_Tbilisi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kunsthalle Tbilisi (page does not exist)")^[\[77\]](#cite_note-80)^^[\[78\]](#cite_note-81)^ and Open Space of Experimental Art,^[\[79\]](#cite_note-82)^ were founded in 2018. Among many other museums, there are the [Giorgi Leonidze State Museum of Literature](/wiki/Giorgi_Leonidze_State_Museum_of_Literature "Giorgi Leonidze State Museum of Literature") and the [Writer's House of Georgia](/wiki/Writer%27s_House_of_Georgia "Writer's House of Georgia").{#cite_ref-82}
