\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/National_Opera_House._Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-National_Opera_House._Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Opera_House._Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) [Tbilisi Opera and Ballet Theatre](/wiki/Tbilisi_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre "Tbilisi Opera and Ballet Theatre")

The city has important theatre and music institutions, such as the [Tbilisi State Conservatoire](/wiki/Tbilisi_State_Conservatoire "Tbilisi State Conservatoire"), the [Tbilisi Opera and Ballet Theatre](/wiki/Tbilisi_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre "Tbilisi Opera and Ballet Theatre"), the [Shota Rustaveli State Academic Theatre](/wiki/Rustaveli_State_Academic_Theater "Rustaveli State Academic Theater"), [Marjanishvili State Academic Theatre](/wiki/Marjanishvili_Theater "Marjanishvili Theater"), [Rezo Gabriadze](/wiki/Rezo_Gabriadze "Rezo Gabriadze") Marionette Theatre and Royal District Theatre.  

#### Film Festival {#Film_Festival}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Film Festival")\]

The [Tbilisi International Film Festival](/wiki/Tbilisi_International_Film_Festival "Tbilisi International Film Festival") (TIFF) is hosted by the Cinema Art Center, Prometheus. It was first held in 2000, within a larger framework of festivals called Gift, until the Prometheus centre was established in 2002, after which it has been held there.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-83)^^[\[81\]](#cite_note-84)^ It is located at 164 Agmashenebeli Avenue.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}  

### World Book Capital {#World_Book_Capital}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: World Book Capital")\]

Tbilisi was designated as the [World Book Capital](/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") for 2021 by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO").^[\[83\]](#cite_note-86)^{#cite_ref-86}  

Tourism {#Tourism}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Tourism")\]

Georgia's growing popularity as an international tourist destination has put Tbilisi on the global travel map. With the country hosting more than 9 million international visitors in 2019, the capital saw major investments in the hospitality industry. It now is the leading tourist destination in the region, offering exquisite cityscapes, Art Deco, Russian, Eastern and Soviet architecture, national museums and galleries, cultural attractions, festivals, historical landmarks and exceptional, traditional Georgian cuisine along with a wide range of international restaurants. The city is well-known, due to its complicated history, as a melting pot of cultures, a diverse metropolis with a palette of attractions.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-87)^{#cite_ref-87}  

### Main sights {#Main_sights}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Main sights")\]  
Main article: [List of museums in Tbilisi](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Tbilisi "List of museums in Tbilisi")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/National_Gallery%2C_Rustaveli_Avenue%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-National_Gallery%2C_Rustaveli_Avenue%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Gallery,_Rustaveli_Avenue,_Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) [Tbilisi Art Gallery](/wiki/Tbilisi_Art_Gallery "Tbilisi Art Gallery")

Tbilisi has important landmarks and sightseeing locations. The [Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Georgia "Parliament of Georgia") and the government ([State Chancellery](/w/index.php?title=State_Chancellery&action=edit&redlink=1 "State Chancellery (page does not exist)")) buildings of Georgia, the [Supreme Court of Georgia](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Georgia_(country) "Supreme Court of Georgia (country)"), the [Sameba Cathedral](/wiki/Sameba_Cathedral "Sameba Cathedral"), the [Vorontsov](/wiki/Vorontsov "Vorontsov")'s Palace (also known as the Children's Palace today), the [National Public Library of the Parliament of Georgia](/wiki/National_Parliamentary_Library_of_Georgia "National Parliamentary Library of Georgia"), the [National Bank of Georgia](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Georgia "National Bank of Georgia"), [Tbilisi Circus](/wiki/Tbilisi_Circus "Tbilisi Circus"), [The Bridge of Peace](/wiki/The_Bridge_of_Peace_(Georgia) "The Bridge of Peace (Georgia)"), and many state museums are in Tbilisi. During the Soviet times, Tbilisi continuously ranked in the top four cities in the Soviet Union for the number of museums.

Out of the city's historic landmarks, the most notable are the [Narikala fortress](/wiki/Narikala_fortress "Narikala fortress") (4th--17th century), [Anchiskhati Basilica](/wiki/Anchiskhati_Basilica "Anchiskhati Basilica") (6th century, built up in the 16th century), [Sioni Cathedral](/wiki/Tbilisi_Sioni_Cathedral "Tbilisi Sioni Cathedral") (8th century, later rebuilt), and [Church of Metekhi](/wiki/Church_of_Metekhi "Church of Metekhi"), Open Air Museum of Ethnography, Sulfur Bath, and Tbilisi Old City.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Leghvtakhevi_or_Abanotubani%2C_Tbilisi_%E1%83%9A%E1%83%94%E1%83%A6%E1%83%95%E1%83%97%E1%83%90%E1%83%AE%E1%83%94%E1%83%95%E1%83%98_17.jpg/220px-Leghvtakhevi_or_Abanotubani%2C_Tbilisi_%E1%83%9A%E1%83%94%E1%83%A6%E1%83%95%E1%83%97%E1%83%90%E1%83%AE%E1%83%94%E1%83%95%E1%83%98_17.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leghvtakhevi_or_Abanotubani,_Tbilisi_%E1%83%9A%E1%83%94%E1%83%A6%E1%83%95%E1%83%97%E1%83%90%E1%83%AE%E1%83%94%E1%83%95%E1%83%98_17.jpg) [Abanotubani](/wiki/Abanotubani "Abanotubani")  

### Nightlife {#Nightlife}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Nightlife")\]

Beyond traditional attractions, Tbilisi has developed burgeoning nightclub culture which started to attract international media attention in the 2010s. The leading clubs such as [Bassiani](/wiki/Bassiani "Bassiani"), Mtkvarze, Khidi, and Café Gallery have featured major international DJs as well as local performers. Due to the growing queer nightlife scene the city is also home to several underground [LGBTQ+](/wiki/LGBTQ%2B "LGBTQ+") venues.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-guardian-88)^^[\[86\]](#cite_note-89)^^[\[87\]](#cite_note-90)^{#cite_ref-90}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Vake_District%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-Vake_District%2C_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vake_District,_Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) High-rise residential and office buildings in [Vake](/wiki/Vake,_Tbilisi "Vake, Tbilisi").

With a nominal GDP of 32 billion [Georgian lari](/wiki/Georgian_lari "Georgian lari") ([€](/wiki/Euro "Euro")10 billion) in 2022, Tbilisi is the economic center of the country, generating more than half of Georgia's GDP. Its GDP per capita of 26,769 Georgian lari (€8,700) is exceeding the national average by more than 50 percent.^[\[6\]](#cite_note-gdp-6)^ The service sector itself is dominated by the wholesale and retail trade sector, reflecting the role of Tbilisi as transit and logistics hub for the country and the South Caucasus. The manufacturing sector contributes only 12 percent to Tbilisi's GDP, but is much larger, by employment and total value added, than the manufacturing sectors in any other region of Georgia. The unemployment rate in Tbilisi is -- with 22.5 percent -- significantly higher in Tbilisi than in the regions.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/P1000074_%288849563928%29.jpg/220px-P1000074_%288849563928%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:P1000074_(8849563928).jpg) [Tbilisi International Airport](/wiki/Tbilisi_International_Airport "Tbilisi International Airport")

The public transport system and the relevant infrastructure in Tbilisi is primarily managed by the Transport and Urban Development Agency. After decades of poor transport services and the prioritization of private vehicles, the city has invested heavily in developing a green, extensive and diverse public transit network since the 2010s. Today, the city is served by an international airport, metro and national rail services, municipal buses, minibuses, cabs, cable cars, bike lanes and a funicular.  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Airport")\]  
Main article: [Tbilisi International Airport](/wiki/Tbilisi_International_Airport "Tbilisi International Airport")

[Shota Rustaveli Tbilisi International Airport](/wiki/Tbilisi_International_Airport "Tbilisi International Airport") is Tbilisi's only international airport, located about 18 kilometres (11 miles) southeast of the city center. Handling 2.99 million passengers in 2022, it is the busiest airport in Georgia and the [twentieth busiest airport in the former Soviet Union](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_the_former_USSR "List of the busiest airports in the former USSR"). The airport has been rapidly growing over the past decade, handling more than 3.56 million passengers in 11 months of 2018.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-92)^ It is a hub for the national carrier [Georgian Airways](/wiki/Georgian_Airways "Georgian Airways") and Georgian-Chinese start-up [Myway Airlines](/wiki/MyWay_Airlines "MyWay Airlines"). Various international carriers serve routes to major European and Asian hubs, such as London, Munich, Berlin, Amsterdam, Dubai, Brussels, Milan, Vienna, Paris, and Doha. The Irish ultra-low-cost carrier [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair") started operating from the airport in 2019.{#cite_ref-92}

Tbilisi International Airport in 2016 started to utilize solar energy and became the first "green airport" in the Caucasus region in 2008.

[Natakhtari Airfield](/wiki/Natakhtari_Airfield "Natakhtari Airfield"), located 33 km north of Tbilisi in the town of [Natakhtari](/wiki/Natakhtari "Natakhtari"), is a domestic airport serving the capital on routes to [Batumi](/wiki/Batumi "Batumi"), [Mestia](/wiki/Mestia "Mestia") and [Ambrolauri](/wiki/Ambrolauri "Ambrolauri").  

### Metro {#Metro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Metro")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Merto_Station_TAVISUPLEBIS_MOEDANI.jpg/220px-Merto_Station_TAVISUPLEBIS_MOEDANI.jpg)](/wiki/File:Merto_Station_TAVISUPLEBIS_MOEDANI.jpg)  
[Tbilisi Metro](/wiki/Tbilisi_Metro "Tbilisi Metro"), known for its depth, provides 9 million rides per month.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Tbilisi_Funicular%2C_Georgia_%2850494491213%29.jpg/220px-Tbilisi_Funicular%2C_Georgia_%2850494491213%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tbilisi_Funicular,_Georgia_(50494491213).jpg)  
Tbilisi Funicular  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Tbilisi%27s_new_city_bus_-_MAN_Lion%27s_city_A21_CNG.jpg/220px-Tbilisi%27s_new_city_bus_-_MAN_Lion%27s_city_A21_CNG.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tbilisi%27s_new_city_bus_-_MAN_Lion%27s_city_A21_CNG.jpg)  
Tbilisi's municipal bus [MAN Lion's City](/wiki/MAN_Lion%27s_City "MAN Lion's City") at Shota Rustaveli Ave.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Gare_du_t%C3%A9l%C3%A9ph%C3%A9rique_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Gare_du_t%C3%A9l%C3%A9ph%C3%A9rique_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gare_du_t%C3%A9l%C3%A9ph%C3%A9rique_-_panoramio.jpg)  
Aerial tramway connecting Europe Square to [Narikala](/wiki/Narikala "Narikala"), the fortress that overlooks the city.  
Main article: [Tbilisi Metro](/wiki/Tbilisi_Metro "Tbilisi Metro")

The [Tbilisi Metro](/wiki/Tbilisi_Metro "Tbilisi Metro") serves the city with [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") subway services. More than 400,000 journeys are made on the system every single day. It was the Soviet Union's fourth metro system. Construction began in 1952 and was finished in 1966.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-93)^ The system operates two lines, the [Akhmeteli-Varketili Line](/wiki/Akhmeteli-Varketili_Line "Akhmeteli-Varketili Line") and the [Saburtalo Line](/wiki/Saburtalo_Line "Saburtalo Line"). It has 23 stations and 186 metro cars. Most stations, characteristic to Soviet-built metro systems, are extravagantly decorated. Trains run from 6:00 am to midnight. Due to the uneven ground, the rail lines run above ground in some areas. Two of the stations are above ground.{#cite_ref-93}

In 2020, it was announced by the city government that the metro system is set for a major upgrade with the renovation of all stations, targeting more sustainable and modern design, as well as step-free wheelchair accessibility. Moreover, Tbilisi will purchase 40 new, modern train cars, or 10 trains, becoming the first major rolling stock upgrade in the network's more than 50-year-old history.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}

The third overground line is planned to connect central Tbilisi with suburbs and [Tbilisi International Airport](/wiki/Tbilisi_International_Airport "Tbilisi International Airport") with a possible extension to [Rustavi](/wiki/Rustavi "Rustavi"), 30 km east of Tbilisi.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}  

### Rail {#Rail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Rail")\]

Tbilisi is the busiest intersection of [Georgian Railways](/wiki/Georgian_Railways "Georgian Railways") services, primarily centred within [Tbilisi Central Railway Station](/wiki/Tbilisi_railway_station "Tbilisi railway station"). From there, the national rail operator offers inter-city services to [Batumi](/wiki/Batumi "Batumi"), [Zugdidi](/wiki/Zugdidi "Zugdidi"), [Poti](/wiki/Poti "Poti"), [Ozurgeti](/wiki/Ozurgeti "Ozurgeti"), [Kutaisi](/wiki/Kutaisi "Kutaisi") and other large cities, as well as several suburban rail services.  

### Buses {#Buses}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Buses")\]

Tbilisi's bus network forms a crucial backbone of the city's transit system. For almost a decade, up to 700 outdated buses of various size were serving the city, majority of them were [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") [Bogdan](/wiki/Bogdan_(bus_company) "Bogdan (bus company)") A144 and A092 models. Nowadays the city has an extensive network of municipal buses, including a growing number of night bus services. In August 2020, the mayor of Tbilisi [Kakha Kaladze](/wiki/Kakha_Kaladze "Kakha Kaladze") announced major changes in the existing public transit system. Notably, the city will have 10 [Bus Rapid Transit](/wiki/Bus_Rapid_Transit "Bus Rapid Transit") corridors in the near future, served by large 18-meter-long buses running at significantly shorter intervals. These services are named TBT (Tbilisi Bus Transit) lines and are indexed numbers from 300 until 310. Besides the TBT lines, the new system includes 44 city and 185 local lines, totalling up to over 240 bus routes within the city.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

The initial reorganization of the bus network started in 2016 when then-mayor [Davit Narmania](/wiki/Davit_Narmania "Davit Narmania") started an ambitious project in efforts to revamp the outdated fleet. Under his city government, 143 energy-efficient [MAN Lion's City](/wiki/MAN_Lion%27s_City "MAN Lion's City") buses were purchased and delivered in 2017.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-97)^ Later, in 2018, a tender was announced to order 90 new buses. Tegeta Truck \& Bus won the tender and delivered 90 Man Lion's City low floor buses to the city in early 2019.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-98)^ Later on, the city purchased more than 400 new buses from two different manufacturers, including 12-meter-long, low floor BMC vehicles and shorter, 8.5-meter-long Isuzu city buses. It was also announced that the city will buy 200 18-meter-long articulated buses in the near future in hopes of further expanding the city's bus network and decreasing intervals.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}  

### Cycling {#Cycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Cycling")\]

Cycling has become increasingly popular among the residents of Tbilisi over the past few years. For decades, this green mode of transport was seen unfit for the mountainous and uneven terrain of the city. However, as the city's government started introducing new bike lanes across the city, a rising number of people turned towards bikes for regular use. One of the first major central Tbilisi bike lanes opened along Pekini Avenue in 2017, following a long rehabilitation process.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-100)^ The 2.8 meter wide lane failed to attract regular users amid the lack of a greater, city-wide network. Soon the city unveiled more bike lanes, including within recreational areas, such as the [National Botanical Garden of Georgia](/wiki/National_Botanical_Garden_of_Georgia "National Botanical Garden of Georgia") and [Lisi Lake](/wiki/Lisi_Lake "Lisi Lake").{#cite_ref-100}

The expansion of the city's [cycling infrastructure](/wiki/Cycling_infrastructure "Cycling infrastructure") network was significantly accelerated during the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic") as cities across the globe started organizing pop-up bike lanes. Tbilisi joined the global trend, unveiling cycling lanes in city's central areas, such as Vake, Vera and the bank of the [Kura River](/wiki/Kura_(Caspian_Sea) "Kura (Caspian Sea)"). Following these changes, the total length of Tbilisi's bike lanes increased from 2 km in 2019 to over 20 km in 2020. The head of the city's transport department told Euronews Georgia that Tbilisi is working on a 20-year long urban mobility development strategy. According to the plan, the total length of the bike lane network will eventually reach 350 km across the capital.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

### Tram {#Tram}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Tram")\]  
Main article: [Trams in Tbilisi](/wiki/Trams_in_Tbilisi "Trams in Tbilisi")

Tbilisi had a tram network starting in 1883 with horse-driven trams, followed by electric trams in 1904. After the Soviet Union disintegrated, due to electricity deficit the electric transport went into decline, and finally the only tram line left was closed on 4 December 2006, along with the two remaining trolleybus lines.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-102)^^[\[100\]](#cite_note-103)^ There were plans to construct a modern tram network.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-104)^^[\[102\]](#cite_note-105)^{#cite_ref-105}  

### Minibus {#Minibus}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Minibus")\]

For a long time, the most dominant form of transport was the [minibus](/wiki/Marshrutka "Marshrutka") network. An elaborate minibus system grew in Tbilisi over the early 2000s. Amid the lack of public funding and rundown infrastructure, minibuses emerged as a private initiative and a short-term solution to the city's transportation problem. In 2019, the company operating yellow minibuses in Tbilisi was asked to replace the entire fleet by the end of 2020.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-106)^ However, the process was slowed down and only 300 minibuses were replaced. The mayor of Tbilisi announced that the number of minibuses in Tbilisi will gradually decrease, eventually vanishing from Tbilisi's streets.{#cite_ref-106}

In addition to the city, several lines also serve the surrounding countryside of Tbilisi. Throughout the city, a fixed price is paid regardless of the distance (80 or 50 [tetri](/wiki/Tetri "Tetri") in 2018). For longer trips outside the city, higher fares are common. As of April 2018, there are no predefined stops for the minibus lines, except 14 streets;^[\[104\]](#cite_note-107)^ they are hailed from the streets like taxis and each passenger can exit whenever they prefer.{#cite_ref-107}  

### Aerial tramways {#Aerial_tramways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Aerial tramways")\]

Historically, the city had seven different aerial tramways, but many of them closed after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

Since 2012, a [gondola lift](/wiki/Gondola_lift "Gondola lift") has operated between Rike Park and the [Narikala fortress](/wiki/Narikala_fortress "Narikala fortress"); each gondola can carry up to eight people. The system was built by the Italian manufacturer [Leitner Ropeways](/wiki/Leitner_Ropeways "Leitner Ropeways").^[\[105\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

On 12 October 2016, the Turtle Lake aerial tramway (originally opened in 1965) reopened after seven years out of service. It underwent major reconstruction but kept the old designs of gondolas and stations. This tramway connects [Vake Park](/wiki/Vake_Park "Vake Park") with [Turtle Lake](/wiki/Turtle_Lake_(Tbilisi) "Turtle Lake (Tbilisi)").

On 19 April 2021, another Soviet-era aerial tramway between the State University (Maglivi) and the University Campus (Bagebi) in Saburtalo District (originally opened in 1982) was opened after reconstruction works took place in 2016--2018. The original Italian cabins, produced by Lovisolo and provided by Ceretti \& Tanfani, with a capacity of 40 passengers each, were kept, as were the stations.

In 1990, one of the main aerial trams experienced a major malfunction, causing the [1990 Tbilisi aerial tramway accident](/wiki/1990_Tbilisi_aerial_tramway_accident "1990 Tbilisi aerial tramway accident") and remaining closed ever since.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-109)^ Since October 2017, the aerial tram has been under reconstruction, keeping the old culturally significant lower station but with plans for new gondolas, masts, upper station and other infrastructure. The project is carried out by [Doppelmayr Garaventa Group](/wiki/Doppelmayr_Garaventa_Group "Doppelmayr Garaventa Group").{#cite_ref-109}  

### Funicular {#Funicular}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Funicular")\]

The Tbilisi funicular reopened in 2012 after a multi-year closure. It is a ropeway railway first built in 1905, connecting Chonkadze Street and [Mtatsminda Park](/wiki/Mtatsminda_Park "Mtatsminda Park"), and covering almost 300 m (980 ft) in altitude difference. The top of the hill is the highest point of the city, offering many different views of Tbilisi, and is home to the [Tbilisi TV Broadcasting Tower](/wiki/Tbilisi_TV_Broadcasting_Tower "Tbilisi TV Broadcasting Tower") as well as some amusement rides, including a rollercoaster and a ferris wheel.

The half-way station of the funicular is located near the [Mtatsminda Pantheon](/wiki/Mtatsminda_Pantheon "Mtatsminda Pantheon"), providing easy access to the necropolis.  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tbilisi&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Classical_School_No.1_of_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg/220px-Classical_School_No.1_of_Tbilisi%2C_Georgia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Classical_School_No.1_of_Tbilisi,_Georgia.jpg) Public School Number 1 of Tbilisi, also known as the [First Classical Gymnasium](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school) "Gymnasium (school)")

Tbilisi is home to several major institutions of higher education, including the Tbilisi State Medical University and the Petre Shotadze Tbilisi Medical Academy, famous for their internationally recognized medical education systems. The biggest Georgian university is [Tbilisi State University](/wiki/Tbilisi_State_University "Tbilisi State University") (TSU), which was established on 8 February 1918. TSU is the oldest university in the whole Caucasus region, with up to 25,000 students enrolled and approximately 5,000 faculty members and staff (collaborators).^[\[107\]](#cite_note-110)^ Tbilisi is also home to the largest medical university in the Caucasus region -- [Tbilisi State Medical University](/wiki/Tbilisi_State_Medical_University "Tbilisi State Medical University"), which was founded as the Tbilisi Medical Institute in 1918 and became the Faculty of Medicine within the Tbilisi State University in 1930. Tbilisi State Medical Institute was renamed to Medical University in 1992. Since it operates as an independent educational institution, it has become one of the highest-ranking state-supported institutions of higher education in the Caucasus region. As of 2023, there are over 7,000 undergraduate and 3,000 postgraduate students at the university, of whom about a quarter come from foreign countries.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-111)^^[\[109\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}

Georgia's main and largest technical university, [Georgian Technical University](/wiki/Georgian_Technical_University "Georgian Technical University"), is in Tbilisi. It was founded in 1922 as a polytechnic faculty of the Tbilisi State University. The first lecture was read by world-famous Georgian mathematician Professor Andria Razmadze. It was transformed into an independent institute in 1928, until it was finally granted University status in 1990.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-113)^{#cite_ref-113}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Tbilisi%2C_Georgia_%E2%80%94_Tbilisi_State_University%2C_I_Corpus%27s_front_view.jpg/220px-Tbilisi%2C_Georgia_%E2%80%94_Tbilisi_State_University%2C_I_Corpus%27s_front_view.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tbilisi,_Georgia_%E2%80%94_Tbilisi_State_University,_I_Corpus%27s_front_view.jpg) [Tbilisi State University](/wiki/Tbilisi_State_University "Tbilisi State University"), Building I

Three of the most popular private higher educational institutions in Georgia -- [The University of Georgia (Tbilisi)](/wiki/The_University_of_Georgia_(Tbilisi) "The University of Georgia (Tbilisi)"), [Caucasus University](/wiki/Caucasus_University "Caucasus University"), and the [Free University of Tbilisi](/wiki/Free_University_of_Tbilisi "Free University of Tbilisi") -- are in Tbilisi. The [University of Georgia (Tbilisi)](/wiki/University_of_Georgia_(Tbilisi) "University of Georgia (Tbilisi)") is the largest private University in Georgia, with more than 8,000 international and local students.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-114)^ Soon after its establishment, it became a market leader within the Georgian educational sector. In 2010, the UG received financing from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) for the development of the university's infrastructure and technical equipment.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-115)^ The University of Georgia has various undergraduate and graduate programs, and it was the first Georgian university to offer international certificate programs of the Oracle Corporation, Microsoft, Zend Technologies and Cisco Academy.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

Caucasus University was established in 2004 as an expansion of the Caucasus School of Business (CSB, established in 1998) by a consortium consisting of Tbilisi State University and Georgian Technical University in partnership with Georgia State University (Atlanta, USA).^[\[114\]](#cite_note-117)^^[\[115\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The Free University of Tbilisi was established in 2007 through a merger of two higher education schools: the European School of Management (ESM-Tbilisi) and the Tbilisi Institute of Asia and Africa (TIAA), both of which then became schools within the university. Aside from that, the Free University now comprises six other schools --- Law School, Governance and Social Sciences, Visual Arts and Design (VAADS), Mathematics and Computer Science (MACS), Physics, and Doctoral School in Social and Humanitarian Sciences --- that deliver academic programs at the undergraduate, graduate and doctorate levels. In addition, Free University conducts a wide array of short-term courses and runs several research centers and summer school programs.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-119)^^[\[117\]](#cite_note-120)^{#cite_ref-120}

Tbilisi is home to many foreigners. The number of foreigners living and working in Tbilisi has risen in recent years together with the openings of international schools, businesses, expatriate communities, and online networks. Tbilisi is a very safe city.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-122)^ Most of the expatriates live in [Vake](/wiki/Vake,_Tbilisi "Vake, Tbilisi"), [Vera](/w/index.php?title=Vera,_Tbilisi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vera, Tbilisi (page does not exist)"), [Saburtalo](/wiki/Saburtalo_District "Saburtalo District"), and Dighomi.{#cite_ref-122}

* IWA, the International Women Association, is a non-profit organization founded in 1996; its members and participants are international and Georgian women.
* Expats in Tbilisi was an online support network founded by UN and EU staff spouses in Georgia to support expatriates in finding information and all relevant resources in one place.
* Inter-nation International^[\[120\]](#cite_note-Tbilisi_Sister_Cities-123)^{#cite_ref-Tbilisi_Sister_Cities_123-0}
